Power to grant a lease in respect of land at Kew Gardens
	The Secretary of State’s powers in relation to the management of the RoyalBotanic Gardens, Kew, include the power to grant a lease in respect of landfor a period of up to 150 years.
	Section 5 of the Crown Lands Act 1702 does not apply in respect of a leasegranted in reliance on subsection (1).
	The Secretary of State may grant a lease in reliance on subsection (1) onlyif satisfied that the lease would not have an adverse impact on—
		the outstanding universal value of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, as aWorld Heritage Site, or
		the ability of the Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, tocarry out its functions under section 24 of the National Heritage Act 1983.
	In subsection (3), “World Heritage Site” means a property appearing on theWorld Heritage List kept under article 11(2) of the UNESCO ConventionConcerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage adoptedat Paris on 16 November 1972 (list of properties recognised by the WorldHeritage Committee as having outstanding universal value).
Extent, commencement and short title
	This Act extends to England and Wales only.
	This Act comes into force at the end of the period of two months beginningwith the day on which it is passed.
	This Act may be cited as the Kew Gardens (Leases) Act 2019.
